Mr ADOU s’est vite intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat et vente de bœufs .Sa vente se fait à FAKOLA.  
Fort de ses 30 années d’expériences dans le domaine, Il collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso pour augmenter  son fonds de commerce afin de satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse de grandir et est à son  troisième  prêt. Sa clientèle est essentiellement composée d’hommes.
Mr ADOU compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 4 bœufs. Il s’approvisionne à FAKOLA et à NIENA  .Il effectue ses ventes au comptant.
Mr ADOU espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  subvenir aux besoins de la famille, rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
ADOU was born in December 1962 in MENA, Cercle de KOLONDIEBA, a prefecture in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. He is 52 years old and resides in FAKOLA, in the KOKO district, in a traditional family with his two wives and six children. Early on, he became interested in revenue-generating businesses, especially the buying and selling of cattle. He makes his sales in FAKOLA.  

With a solid thirty years of experience in this domain, he is collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to increase his business capital in order to satisfy his customer base, which is ever-growing. He is on his third loan. His customer base is essentially composed of men. 

Mr. ADOU intends to use his loan to purchase 4 head of cattle. His supply comes from FAKOLA and from NIENA. His sales are made in cash. Mr. ADOU hopes to make a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used to meet family needs, pay back the loan, and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Willian Alfredo

texts.es:
Willian es un joven de 23 años de edad, aplicado y responsable en las actividades que realiza, gracias a la dedicación a los estudios pudo sacar su grado de técnico agrónomo, esto fue posible a través de una beca de estudio que se gano por su esfuerzo. A pesar de las los obstáculos que se le han presentado por  limitantes económicas de su familia, pudo culminar sus estudios satisfactoriamente. Actualmente vive con cinco hermanos menores y su mamá, quien es una madre soltera, pero que ha logrado con mucho trabajo, sacar adelante su familia.
El joven se dedica  a las actividades agrícolas desde temprana edad,junto con sus hermanos cultivan maíz y frijol. Aprendió a cultivar la tierra gracias a su madre. Al trabajar siempre en la agricultura, le ayudo a decidirse la carrera  a estudiaragronomía. Durante los últimos 3 años se ha dedicado plenamente  al estudio en la universidad.
El préstamo lo utilizara para la compra de una motocicleta,  necesita este medio de transporte para desempeñarse en el trabajo . De no tener este medio se le dificultaría encontrar un trabajo, por las actividades que realizaría(asesoría técnica) en la zona rural. Al tener un empleo podrá generar ingreso, ayudando a su madre y hermanos.
Su deseo es poder ayudar a sus hermanos, que sigan estudiando y preparándose. Esta convencido que es la única forma de mejorar las condiciones de vida  de la familia.
texts.en:
Willian is a 23 year old young man, applied and responsible in his activities, thanks to his dedication to his studies, he was able to earn a degree in agriculture.  This was possible through a scholarship he earned.  Despite the obstacles of limited finances, he was able to complete his studies satisfactorily.  He currently lives with five younger siblings and his mother, who is a single mother.  It has been difficult for her to get the family ahead.

This young man has been a farmer from a young age and he and his brothers raise corn and beans.  He learned to work the land from his mother.  Always having worked the land helped him with his studies in agriculture.  For the past three years he has been studying at university.

He will use the money from this loan to buy a motorcycle.  He needs this means of transport for his work.  Not having this means of transport makes it difficult for him to find work (technical advisor) in the rural area.  He will be able to generate an income and help his mother and brothers if he finds a job.

He wants to be able to help his brothers so that they will continue in school and preparing themselves.  He is convinced that this is the only way to improve ones living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia works hard to support her family. She is married and has an abacca-weaving business in the Philippines.

Lucia requested a PHP 26,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy more materials for her business.

Lucia has been in this business for seven years now. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Femme de 37ans, Akouvi est mariée à un enseignant et mère de 02 enfants scolarisés. Pour prêter main forte à son conjoint, elle revend des céréales(mais et du haricot) dans une boutique. Ses approvisionnements se font à Anié(Une ville située à environ 150Km de la ville de Lomé). Son stock ayant connu une baisse, Akouvi fait sa quatrième demande à WAGES pour acheter plus de marchandises. Le profit lui permettra d'assurer l'épanouissement de la famille et de rendre son activité durable.
texts.en: Akouvi is a 37-year old woman. She is married to a teacher and has two children in school. In order to help out her husband, she sells cereals (corn and beans) in a store. She stocks up in the town of Anié, 150 km [93 miles] from Lomé. Since she is running low on stock, Akouvi is seeking her fourth loan from WAGES in order to buy more goods. Her revenue will allow her to ensure the well-being of her family and   stabilize her business.

loans.use: to purchase cereals.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 38 years old, married to Janet, and a father of five children between the ages of five and fifteen. He does welding to earn a living, a business he has done for the last seven years with a monthly income of KES 35,000. He learned about VisionFund Kenya from a neighbor.

Patrick has been advanced a third loan of KES 35,000, which he will use to purchase welding tools. He will use the proceeds to reinvest and expand his business. His hope is to uplift the family's living standards.

loans.use: to buy some welding tools.

loans.name: María Teresa

texts.es:
María de 44 años de edad,  estudió hasta 2º grado, debido a la pobreza en la que vivían sus padres; está casada y su esposo trabaja en la Alcaldía han procreado 4 hijos, 3 ya se acompañaron, solo uno vive con ellos.

Ella  vende tortillas desde hace 2 años, la necesidad la llevó a probar en ese negocio y una señora que vendía en el puesto que ella tiene dejo ese negocio y le propuso que tomara ese puesto y así fué que comenzó, pero antes de dedicarse a vender tortillas se dedicaba al jornal en la agricultura, pues su papá le enseñó el trabajo en el campo, generalmente se levanta a las 4:00 A.M. Para coser el maíz y llevarlo al molino porque comienza a elabora tortillas a las 8:30 A. M., para llegar donde vende tiene que caminar 30 minutos y termina su jornada a las 5:00 PM. esa es su rutina diaria. Las personas que le ayudan son una hija y su esposo.

El préstamo será invertido, una parte para comprar una novilla y la otra para la compra de 3 camionadas de leña y mejorar la champa donde vende las tortillas.

Su deseos son construir una champa mas segura para el negocio,  que su último hijo se gradúe en la Universidad, ya que los otros no quisieron, construirle una habitación a su hijo y con la ganancia de su negocio pagar el crédito para tener las puertas abiertas.
texts.en:
Maria is 44 years old. She only studied until the second grade due to her parents living in poverty. She is married and her husband works in the mayor's office. They have four children; three of whom are in relationships and just one child lives with them. She has been selling tortillas for two years. It was out of necessity that she tried this business. The woman who used to sell at this stand left her business. She suggested that Maria take it over and so her business was started. Before she began working in the business of selling tortillas, she worked daily as a farm worker. Her father taught her how to work in the fields. 

She usually wakes up at 4:00 A.M. to sow the corn and carry it to the mill before beginning to make tortillas at 8:30 A.M. In order to arrive to her place of business, she has to walk 30 minutes. She finishes her work day at 5:00 P.M. This is her daily routine. Her daughter and husband help her. 

This loan will be invested; one part in the purchase of a heifer [young cow] and the other part in the purchase of three truckloads of wood to improve the shack where she sells tortillas. 

Her dreams are to build a more secure shack for her business and that her last son will graduate from the university as the others did not want to. She also hopes to build a room for her son, and to repay her loan with the revenue from her business in order to have open doors.

loans.use: to buy a heifer and three truckloads of wood to improve the shack where she sells tortillas.

loans.name: Yacouba

texts.fr:
YACOUBA  est né en Décembre 1974 à SOROMANA, cercle KOLONDIEBA  une des préfectures  de la 3ème Région administrative du Mali. Mr YACOUBA est âgé  de 40 ans. Il réside à FAKOLA dans une famille traditionnelle avec 3 femmes et 5 enfants.
 Mr YACOUBA s’est vite intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat et vente de pièces détachées .Sa vente se fait à FAKOLA.  
Fort de ses 7 années d’expériences dans le domaine, Il collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso pour augmenter  son fonds de commerce afin de satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse de grandir et est à son  deuxième  prêt. Sa clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Mr YACOUBA compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 5 colis de pièces détachées. Il s’approvisionne à FAKOLA à BAMAKO.  Il effectue ses ventes au comptant.
Mr YACOUBA espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  subvenir aux besoins de la famille, rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
YACOUBA was born in December 1974 in SOROMANA, Cercle de KOLONDIEBA, a prefecture in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. He is 40 years old and resides in FAKOLA in a traditional family with three wives and five children. Early on, he became interested in revenue-generating work, especially the buying and selling of spare parts. He makes his sales in FAKOLA.  

With a solid seven years of experience in this domain, he is collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to increase his business capital in order to satisfy his customer base, which is ever-growing. He is on his second loan. His customer base is composed of men and women. 

Mr. YACOUBA intends to use his loan to purchase 5 packages of spare parts. His supply comes from FAKOLA and from BAMAKO. His sales are made in cash. Mr. YACOUBA hopes to make a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA that will be used to meet family needs, pay back the loan, and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts

loans.name: Wael

texts.en:
Wael is a 30-year-old married father of two children who has been working in selling fresh chicken since ten years ago.

He is a hard worker who puts so much effort in developing his business and increasing his income, to make sure that he is capable of covering his precious family's needs and requests.

Wael is acquiring a youth loan from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua, to buy a special feather plucker, which is necessary for his business production and cleanliness.
 
Wael is working hard so that in the near future, he will invest some money to make some maintenance to his shop to keep it attractive enough for his current and future customers.

loans.use: to buy a special feather plucker.

loans.name: Yaya

texts.fr:
YAYA  est né en 1983 à SOCOURANI commune de FAKOLA ; cercle de KOLONDIEBA une des préfectures de la 3ème Région administrative du Mali. Mr YAYA est âgé de 31 ans. Il réside à SOCOURANI dans une famille traditionnelle avec 10 enfants.
 Mr YAYA s’est vite intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat et vente de céréales .Sa vente se fait à SOCOURANI.  
Fort de ses 5 années d’expériences dans le domaine, Il collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso pour augmenter  son fonds de commerce afin de satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse de grandir et est à son  deuxième  prêt. Sa clientèle est composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Mr YAYA compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 20 sacs de maïs et 20 sacs de mil. Il s’approvisionne à SOCOURANI et environs. Il effectue ses ventes au comptant et parfois à crédit.
Mr YAYA espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  subvenir aux besoins de la famille, rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
YAYA was born in 1983 in SOCOURANI, Commune de FAKOLA, Cercle de KOLONDIEBA, a prefecture in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. He is 31 years old and resides in SOCOURANI in a traditional family with ten children. Early on, he became interested in revenue-generating work, especially the buying and selling of grains. He makes his sales in FAKOLA.  

With a solid five years of experience in this domain, he is collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to increase his business capital in order to satisfy his customer base, which is ever-growing. He is on his second loan. His customer base is composed of men and women. 

Mr. YAYA intends to use his loan to purchase 20 sacks of corn and 20 sacks of millet. His supplies come from SOCOURANI and nearby. His sales are made in cash and sometimes on credit. Mr. YAYA hopes to make a monthly profit of 120,000 francs CFA that will be used to meet family needs, pay back the loan, and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: to purchase grains

loans.name: Jose Marbin

texts.es: MARVIN ESTUDIO HASTA PRIMER GRADO, SU ESPOSA LE AYUDA CON LO POCO QUE RECIBE DEL TRABAJO QUE DESEMPEÑA, TIEN DOS HIJOS SOLAMENTE LA MAYOR ESTUDIA OCTAVO GRADO EL MENOR DE LOS HIJOS AUN NO ESTUDI NO TIENE LA EDAD NECESARIA. EL ES SOLDADO DESDE HACE TRECE AÑOS Y DECIDIO DEDICARSE A ESTE TRABAJO POR LA SITUACION ECONOMICA Y LA NECESIDAD DE SU FAMILIA, ADEMAS ES JORNALERO EL LLEGA A SU CASA A LAS DOS SEMANAS, DICE EL SEÑOR QUE EL CREDITO LO UTILIZARA PARA RECONSTRUIR SU VIVIENDA YA QUE ESTA EN MUY MAL ESTADO, COMPRARA LAMINA, MADERA Y PAGARA MANO Y ASI SU FAMILIA PUEDA VIVIR MEJOR.EL ESPRA SEGUIR AYUDANDO A SU FAMILIA Y SOBRE TODO A SUS HIJOS PARA QUE SALGAN ADELTANTE Y SEAN PROFESIONALES Y AYUDARLE A SU ESPOSA PARA QUE SE DEDIQUE DE LLENO A SU TRANBBAJO COMO MAQUILLISTA.
texts.en:
Marvin studied only through 1st grade. His wife helps out with the little she receives from her work. They have just 2 children; the elder is in the 8th grade, while the younger is underage and doesn't study yet. Marvin has been a soldier for 13 years. He decided to undertake this work due to his family's needs and their economic situation. In addition, he is a day laborer. Marvin will arrive at his house [to undertake the work] in 2 weeks.

He intends to use the loan to reconstruct their home because it is in very bad condition, purchasing sheeting and lumbar and paying day laborers. As a result, his family will live better.

Marvin intends to continue helping his family and, above all, his children, so they can get ahead and become professionals. He also wishes to help his wife so that she can dedicate herself full time to her work as a beautician.

loans.use: to purchase sheeting and wood and to pay workers for helping reconstruct his house.

loans.name: Nubia Nohemy

texts.es:
Nubia de 31 años de edad, estudió hasta 9º grado,  debido a la falta de recursos económicos tuvo que abandonar la escuela, está acompañada, su pareja trabaja como albañil, tiene 2 hijos y están el la escuela, nadie mas vive con ellos.

Nubia se dedica a confeccionar uniformes desde que tiene 18 años, comenta que cuando ella salió de noveno  grado sus padres ya no ajustaron para enviarla a estudiar,  pues eran 7 hermanos, debido a esa situación se vio en la necesidad de buscar trabajo y una amiga le consiguió en una maquila y así aprendió el oficio, es una persona luchadora pues dice que ha hecho de todo, trabaja como domestica, vendiendo en un cafetin, vendiendo pan y actualmente lleva 2 años de trabajar en  un taller de costura donde confeccionan uniformes para 4 escuelas, su jornada comienza a las 4:30 AM. para salir a tiempo de preparar el desayuno a su familia y preparar a sus niños para ir a la escuela, ella entra a trabajar a las 7:30 AM. y sale a las 4:00 PM, pero para ganar otros dolares sale a las 5:00 PM, para llegar a su trabajo camina 20 minutos, esa es su rutina diaria.



El préstamo será invertido para comprar 3 puertas de hierro, ya que las que tiene son de tabla y están deterioradas y otra parte para construir un servicio sanitario.

Sus sueños son  tener su propio taller de costura, preparar a sus hijos con una profesión, ella anhela seguir estudiando y pagar el crédito para tener las puertas abiertas en la instituciòn.
texts.en:
Nubia is 31 years old and went as far as ninth grade in school, as due to the lack of financial resources she had to leave school. She lives with her partner, who works in construction. She has two children and they are in school. No one else lives with them.

Nubia has been sewing uniforms for 18 years. She says that when she left ninth grade her parents could no longer afford to send her to school, as there were seven siblings. 

Due to that situation she felt it necessary to look for work, and a friend got her into an assembly plant and that's how she learned the occupation. She is a determined person as she says she has done a little bit of everything. She works as a house keeper, selling at a small café, selling bread, and currently has been working in a sewing workshop where they make uniforms for four schools. Her day begins at 4:00 a.m., so that she can get up in time to make breakfast for the family and prepare her children for going to school. She gets to work at 7:00 a.m. and leaves at 4:00 p.m. but in order to earn extra dollars she goes out at 5:00 p.m. and to get to her work walks for 20 minutes. That is her daily routine. 

The loan will be used to buy three steel doors, as the ones she has are of wood and are in poor condition. The rest is to build a bathroom. Her dream is to have her own sewing workshop and help her children become professionals. She wishes to continue studying and pay off the loan so that the doors remain open for her at the institution.

loans.use: to buy three metal doors for her home, as the ones she has now are of wooden boards and in poor condition, and the rest to build a bathroom.

loans.name: Luís Alonso

texts.es:
Luis de 56 años de edad, es una persona muy honesta y trabajadora que se dedica a la agricultura desde muy pequeño y esa actividad es la cual ha realizado por largo tiempo y que ha sido la única fuente de ingreso de donde ha podido sacar a delante a su familia. En la actualidad vive solo con su esposa, aunque su familia está formada por 4 hijos los cuales ya están separados, tienen su propio hogar. Solo una hija vive con el cliente, pero no depende directamente de él,  porque es una joven trabajadora que se dedica a su trabajo de maestra y que es de donde le ayuda a sus padres.

Luis, se dedica a la agricultura desde que tenía 16 años, porque su padre fue una persona que toda su vida se dedicó a cultivar la tierra y es así como desde muy pequeño, inicio a conocer de las actividades que requiere un cultivo de maíz, maicillo o frijol y es así como hoy en día agradece esas acciones que su padre le enseño porque, conoce de mucho sobre la agricultura y difícilmente alguien podrá mentirle en las actividades que se requieren en ese cultivo.

 Además de la agricultura, el cliente a aprendido otras actividades, como la ganadería de donde tiene también sus alimentos y esto lo ha realizado poco a poco, con mucho esfuerzo compro una vaca, la cual fue el principio de unas actividades que el cliente desconocía. Pero gracias a la ayuda de unos amigos y el apoyo económico que credicampo, le ha dado al cliente ha ido fortaleciendo su trabajo y es gracias a todo eso que es una persona de muchos conocimientos, en agricultura y ganadería.

El dinero que solicita será destinado para la compra de una vaca, que según el cliente es de buena productora de  leche, su precio oscila por los $900 y con esto estará mejorando su hato de ganadero y la producción de leche. El resto del dinero sera utilizado para la preparación del terreno donde cultiva que son 14,000 metros cuadrados.     

Uno de sus grandes sueños y que espera primeramente en Dios le de fuerza, para cumplirlo es mejorar su ganado esto significa vender las vacas que ya tiene y comprar vacas de razas productoras de leche y así mejorar los ingresos a su familia.
texts.en:
Luís, 56 years old, is a very honest and hard-working person who has worked in agriculture since he was very young. This activity is what he has done for a long time, and it has been the only source of income from which he has been able to move his family forward. Currently he lives only with his wife, although his family is made up of 4 children who are already independent and have their own homes. Only one daughter lives with him, but she does not depend directly on him because she is a hard-working young person who works as a teacher, and that is how she helps her parents.

Luís has worked in agriculture since he was 16 years old because his father was a person who cultivated the land his whole life. This is how, since he was very young, he began to learn about the activities required for a corn, sorghum, or bean crop. Today he is thankful for those actions that his father taught him because he knows a lot about agriculture and it would be hard for someone to be able to lie to him about the activities required for those crops.

In addition to agriculture, he has learned other activities, such as ranching, from which he also gets his food. This he has done little by little. With a lot of effort he bought a cow, which was the first of several activities he did not know about. But thanks to the help of some friends and the economic support Credicampo has given him, he has strengthened his work. It is thanks to all of that that he is a person who knows a lot about agriculture and ranching.

The money he is requesting will be used to buy a cow, which according to Luis is a good milk producer. Its price is around $900 and with this he will be improving his cattle herd and milk production. The rest of the money will be used to prepare the land he cultivates, which is 14,000 square meters.

One of his greatest dreams, and he hopes God gives him the strength to achieve it, is to improve his cattle. This means selling the cows he already has and buying dairy cows, and in this way improving his family's income.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a lady of forty six years, married, and a mother of five children. She runs a preschool in Ngaraiga, in the outskirts of Limuru. She has been in this business for five years, and gets a monthly income of 6,200 KES.

This will be Josephine's first loan with VisionFund Kenya. She plans to use the entire loan to buy school text books and uniforms for her students. In the future, she wants to expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: to purchase school text books and uniforms.

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel raises pigs and has been doing this for many years. Aside from this, she also had a farm, which is the main source of income for the family. She had successfully repaid her previous loan used for farm inputs.

In their village, she  had to make money in many ways to earn other than farming. She also operates a sari sari store to gain more returns. Recently, she took a new loan to purchase additional grocery goods to resell.

In the future, Maricel wants to make improvements on her house and see her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to purchase additional grocery goods to resell

loans.name: Lorife

texts.en:
Lorife is married with four children. Lorife is 28 years old and lives in Brgy. IV, Tangub city, Misamis Occidental.

To earn a living, Lorife has a retail business. She has had this business for four years. Each month, she earns approximately PHP 10,000. Lorife has been a member of PMPC for five years.

Lorife had loan from PMPC worth PHP 14,000 to pay for housing materials to build a house for her parents.

In the future, Lorife hopes to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy housing materials for building a house for her parents.

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en:
Ma. Fe is 45 years old and married with one kid who is in school. Ma. Fe works very hard to provide for them.

Ma. Fe runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 9,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more stocks of groceries to resell.

Ma. Fe has been in this business for ten years, and sells a variety of items, such as sugar, snack foods, and other groceries. 

In the future Ma. Fe would like to save money to expand her business and repair her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of groceries to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy float for mobile money transfer

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a thirty-two-year-old married man with three children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has been in the photography business for the last seven years. He started this business so as to employ himself and be independent from other people. He faces a hardship of limited capital as his business is seasonal but has hopes of constructing rentals to generate additional income. James is requesting a loan to buy a Canon digital camera.

loans.use: to buy a Canon digital camera.

loans.name: Inaam

texts.en:
Inaam is a 57-year-old single lady who runs her convenience store to cover her own living and another member of her family's living, and where she represents the family's sole breadwinner.

She is requesting a loan from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua, to increase her business merchandise with special spring and summer beverages and special offer products, to increase her income and improve her living. 

This is Inaam’s seventh loan cycle from Al Majmoua. She is a client with good standing history. Her previous loans were also invested in developing her business, and came with a good standing feedback.

Most of her customers like dealing with her, and they state that she is a very welcoming person with special customer service, which they enjoy acquiring.

Lately, she started selling women clothes to diversify her income. She hopes to expand both businesses and open a supermarket and a clothes selling shop in the future.

loans.use: to increase her business merchandise with special spring and summer beverages and special offer products.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a fifty-nine-year-old father of three grown-up children. He is from Thika and has a business as a mixed crop farmer. He is married to Teresia, who helps him in farming. He earns a monthly income of KES 20,000 which he uses to support himself and his family. 

This marks his fourth loan term with VISIONFUND KENYA. With this loan, he will be able to purchase poultry feed. The additional income created will allow him improve his family's standard of living as well as ploughing some money back into his business. In the future, Peter would like to become a large-scale farmer. 

He hopes to have a comfortable life together with his family.

loans.use: to purchase poultry feed

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a single entrepreneur who makes a living to support her needs and help her parents. She has been raising pigs for more than five years, and she earns well from this. She heard about GDMPC before, and just recently decide to join. 

She gained access to micro-finance services and borrowed a loan to purchase piglets to raise. Improving her piggery is her priority, for she can find better income from this. In the future, she wants to improve the general living of her family.

loans.use: to purchase piglets to raise.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen, a 34-year-old married mother of three in Thika, runs a general shop. She is married to George, who is a full-time preacher. Their children are 13, 9, and 7 years respectively. 

She currently lacks enough funds needed to purchase more stock to serve her ever-growing customer base. With a loan through VisionFund Kenya, Hellen will be able to purchase 10 bags of sugar and 10 bags of rice. Hellen is requesting her third loan, having completed repaying all her previous loans successfully. The additional income created will allow her to reinvest in her business. 

In the future, Hellen would like to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase 10 bags of sugar and 10 bags of rice

loans.name: Ruhshona

texts.en: Ruhshona is a smart woman. She is married. Ruhshona is a woman who always tries for the well-being of her family. She has her own business deal. She sells children's clothes in a shop. Her shop is located near her house. She walks there every day. Ruhshona’s working day begins at 7 o’clock in the morning. She works six days in a week. Ruhshona has been busy with this business for more than 1 year and 6 months. She manages her business successfully. She is going to increase her working capital but she does not have enough money. She is asking for a loan of 5,000 Somoni to buy children's clothes for increasing her working capital.

loans.use: To buy children's clothes for increasing her working capital

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is 36 years old and a married mother of five children. Four of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.  

Evelyn has a fish vending business in the Philippines. Evelyn requested a PHP 18,000 loan amount through NWTF in order to buy more fish to resell.

Evelyn has been in this business for twenty years. In the future, Evelyn would like to save money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish to resell.

loans.name: Andrea

texts.es:
Andrea tiene 56 años de edad, debido a la difícil situación económica que atravesaba su familia ella no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar, por lo cual tuvo que comenzar a trabajar para apoyar a su familia con los ingresos económicos, la señora está soltera, tiene 3 hijos de 20, 16 y 9 años de edad.

Andrea se dedica a los oficios domésticos, sus ingresos provienen de una pensión que recibe del estado, es poca pero le permite cubrir algunos de sus gastos personales, además tiene la ayuda de su hija mayor que trabaja en  una empresa de atún que se encuentra ubicada en la ciudad donde ella reside.

La vivienda de Andrea no se encuentra en muy buenas condiciones, es por ello que está solicita este crédito para mejorar su vivienda, con el dinero comprará lámina, tornillos y polines para colocarle el techo a la casa, de esta forma con el crédito se les estará ayudando a tener una vivienda es buen estado, y estará garantizando su seguridad y la de su familia.

Entre los planes de Andrea están, esforzarse muchísimo para darle la educación a sus hijos y tengan un mejor futuro, que encuentren un trabajo que les permita desarrollarse profesionalmente, y que cada uno de ellos formen sus propias familias.
texts.en:
Andrea, age 56, did not have the opportunity to go to school due to the difficult financial situation that her family had.  Therefore, she had to start to work in order to support the family with her income.  She is single.  She has three children, ages 20, 16, and 9.

Andrea devotes herself to the domestic chores.  Her income comes from a pension that she gets from the state.  It is small, but it allows her to cover some of her personal expenses.  Also, she has help from her oldest daughter, who works for a tuna company in the city where she lives.

Andrea’s house is not in very good condition.  That is why she is requesting the loan to improve her house.  She will use the loan to buy galvanized metal sheeting, screws, and purlins to put on the roof of her house.  In this way the loan will be helping them to have a home in good condition.  She will be guaranteeing the safety of her family.

Andrea’s plans are to put forth great effort in order to give her children an education so that they have a better future.  She plans to do this so that they can find work that will allow them to develop professionally and so that each one of them can form their own family.

loans.use: to buy galvanized metal sheeting, screws, and purlins for the roof of her house.

loans.name: Benjie

texts.en:
Benjie is 39 years old, married, and a resident of Brgy Tugas, Tangub city, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Her husband is a taxi driver. They have four children, three of which are in school. Starting with a capital of 3,000 PHP, she opened a sari-sari (general store) and was able to expand it with the help of Paglaum Cooperative. Aside from financial assistance, she was able to generate savings and enjoy the benefits given by the co-op. She became a member just this year, 2014. 

Now she is applying for 7,000 PHP to buy stocks for her sari-sari store, particularly basic commodities.  In the future, she wants to own a mini-mart someday, and will be fully satisfied if she sees her children finish their studies.

loans.use: to buy additional basic commodities for her sari-sari store.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, a 46-year-old father of three from Thika, has a business as a mixed crop farmer. He is married to Tabitha, who helps him in farming. He earns a monthly income of KES 20,000, which he uses to support himself and his family. 

This marks his third loan term with VisionFund, Kenya. With the loan he has applied for from VisionFund Kenya, he will be able to purchase seedlings and fertilizers for his farm. Additional income created will allow him to improve the standards of living for his family and pay school fees for his children. In the future, John would like to expand his farming to become a large scale farmer. 

He hopes to educate all of his children to college level.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizers.

loans.name: Sophia Chatoma's Group

texts.en:
In Kedeta village, Kisienya sub-location, in Vihiga County, Kenya, Sophia has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Sophia is a hardworking and trustworthy member of the community with 5 children. Sophia lives with her family in a house made up of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.

Kedeta village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Sophia and 30 other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Sophia has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and will also be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine when the tank runs low. Sophia has also volunteered to be the promoter because she likes to work towards her community’s well-being and wants to ensure her community prevents waterborne diseases by always drinking treated water. There are also three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Alex, Margrate and Beatrice.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Sophia’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Luís Alonso

texts.es:
Luís de 45 años de edad, estudio hasta  primer grado en la escuela. Esta  acompañado su esposa se dedica a los oficios domésticos,  tienen tres hijos la primera estudia 1er año de bachillerato y tiene 17 años, la segunda estudia noveno  grado y la tercera estudia octavo grado en la escuela del cantón.
     
El señor se dedica a trabajar como albañil, tiene 20 años de dedicarse a esta actividad, cuando era más joven trabajaba como ayudante de albañil,  es decir haciendo mescla, excavaciones, y cuando tenía varios años de hacer lo mismo decidió empezar otras actividades como pegar bloque, correr niveles etc. Fue así que decidió hacer el trabajo por si solo hasta convertirse en obrero calificado. Otra actividad es la siembra de granos básicos como maíz y frijol. Antes solo era jornalero. La distancia de su trabajo es variable porque termina en un lado y se mueve a trabajar a otro,  por la actividad que realiza. Cuenta que trabaja de 6 am a 2: 30 Pm. Su esposa es la que se involucra indirectamente en la actividad pero llevándole los alimentos a donde está trabajando.

El préstamo que esta solicitando, es para comprar 20 bolsas de cemento, 8 quintales de hierro,  5 quintales  de hierro de 3/8 y 3 quintales de 1/8  para construir su casa.     


El sueño del señor Luis, es construir poco a poco su vivienda y enseguida asignársela a uno de sus hijas para que vivan más tranquilos alejados de todo peligro, por otra parte, pretende ayudar en sus estudios a sus hijas que sean profesionales y puedan tener sus ingresos y sostenerse financieramente por si solas.
texts.en:
Luís is 45 years old, and he has attended school up to the first grade.  He lives with his wife, who is a homemaker, and they have three children. Their first child, who is 17 years old, is studying in the first year of high school, the second child is in the ninth grade, and the third is in eighth grade in the canton school.  

He works in construction, an occupation that he has been engaged in for 20 years. When he was younger he worked as a construction assistant, mixing cement and excavating; and after doing this for several years, he decided to begin doing other things such as laying block, taking levels, etc., working on his own until he became a skilled worker. 

His other occupation is cultivating basic grains such as corn and beans. Before, he was only a day laborer. The distance to his work varies, as when he finishes working at one site, he moves to another. He says that he works from 6:00 a.m. until 2:30 p.m. His wife is involved with his occupation indirectly, bringing him meals wherever he is working.

The loan that he is requesting is for the purchase of 20 bags of cement and 8 quintals (1 quintal = 100 lbs.) of iron rebar (5 quintals of 3/8 rebar, and 3 quintals of 1/8 rebar), in order to build his house.

Luís's dream is to construct his home little by little, and then give it to one of his daughters, so that they can live a quiet life, away from danger.  In addition to this, he is trying to help his daughters with their studies so that they can become professionals and have their own incomes, and support themselves financially.

loans.use: to purchase 20 bags of cement and 8 quintals of iron rebar (5 quintals of 3/8 rebar and 3 quintals of 1/8 rebar), in order to build his house.

loans.name: Charles Kisia's Group

texts.en:
Charles has a family which includes 3 daughters and 2 sons and lives in a house made up of dirt floor, iron roof and mud walls in Chanzaruka village, Vihiga County, Kenya. The community of Chanzaruka village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases which often leads to Chanzaruka’s inhabitants falling sick and children not regularly attending school.


A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water-point where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Chanzaruka, 16 households will gain access to safe water through the chlorine dispenser. Charles has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter because he wants to be actively involved in improving the health and productivity of the community and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine and promoting the use of the dispenser within the community. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Mark, Janet, Noah and Alex.


Chanzaruka village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining their dispensers. Charles believes that the chlorine dispenser will kill bacteria thus help prevent water-borne diseases like diarrhoea. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe for drinking. loans.name: Rosa Delfina

texts.es:
Rosa de 35 años de edad, estudio hasta  tercer grado, esta acompañada, tiene dos hijos el esposo trabaja como albañil y administrador de una finca, sus dos hijos le ayudan en el trabajo a su padre y estudian, con ellos vive la mamá de Rosa y depende totalmente de ella. Desde hace cuatro años Rosa trabaja con una vecina a la que le cuida y hace los oficios del hogar tres veces por semana y en sus tiempos libres, también hace trabajos en la finca de sus mamá, el trabajo lo realiza en el mismo lugar donde vive. 

Rosa necesita construir una habitación a la casa, el cual destinara como baño, ya lo tiene empezado pero el dinero con el que cuenta no es suficiente para terminarlo, cree que con el préstamo lograra terminarlo en poco tiempo. Dice Rosa que con el crédito mejorara su casa y que le dará estudio a sus hijos y que la finca de su madre la abonara y la cuidara para obtener ingresos pues por el momento la ha descuidado por la situación económica.
texts.en:
Rosa, 35 years old, studied through third grade. She has a partner and two children. Her husband works as a construction worker and as an administrator on a farm. Her two children help their father with the work and study. Rosa's mother lives with them and depends completely on her. For four years, Rosa has worked with a neighbor, for whom she cares and does housework three times a week. In her free time, she also does work on her mother's farm. She does the work at the same place where she lives.

Rosa needs to build a room in her house, which will be used as a bathroom. She has already started it, but the money she has is not sufficient to finish it. She believes that with the loan, she will be able to finish it in a short amount of time. Rosa says that with the loan she will improve her house, that she will send her children to school, and that she will fertilize and care for her mother's farm in order to obtain income, since for the moment she has neglected it due to the economic situation.

loans.use: to build a room in her house that will be used as a bathroom

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en:
Rose is 59 years old, has 6 children and lives in Kilindiru village in Vihiga County, Kenya. Kilindiru village community collect their water from a protected spring because they don’t have a piped water supply. As a result, their water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Rose and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Rose works as a commercial farmer but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Rose and other promoters in her community, including Rhoda, Rose, Tom and Wilson, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Rose will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Rose wants to be a promoter because she loves working for her community and she believes that treated water will help fight water-borne diseases, leading to a better and healthy community.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Through using chlorine dispenser to treat water instead of boiling water to make it safe to drink, the community will generate carbon credits. The sale of these carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Rose’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Ezibe's Group

texts.en:
Ezibe lives in Ikumba village, Vihiga County, Kenya, in a house made of concrete walls, concrete floor and iron roof. She has a family which includes 4 children. In Ikumba village, there is no piped water supply and so the community collects their drinking water from a protected spring. The water from the spring can be easily contaminated with bacteria that often make Ikumba inhabitants sick and unable to work, or even worse, prevent their children from regularly attending school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Ikumba village, 80 households will benefit from the dispenser by having access to safe water. Ezibe has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter because she cares about her community’s health and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine. With chlorine dispenser in use, Ezibe foresees a happy and healthy community free of water-borne diseases. There are several other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan including: Eunice, Rose, Jesca and Job.

Ikumba village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Ezibe’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.name: Broulaye

texts.fr:
BROULAYE est né en Décembre 1979 à SAMAKONI; cercle de KOLONDIEBA une des préfectures  de la 3ème Région administrative du Mali. Mr BROULAYE est âgé de 35 ans. Il réside à SAMAKONI dans une famille traditionnelle avec 3 femmes et 5 enfants.
Mr BROULAYE s’est vite intéressé aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat et vente de boeufs.Sa vente se fait à SAMAKONI.  
Fort de ses 4 années d’expériences dans le domaine, Il collabore avec Soro Yiriwaso pour augmenter  son fonds de commerce afin de satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse de grandir et est à son  troisième  prêt. Sa clientèle est composée d’hommes.
Mr BROULAYE compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 4 bœufs. Il s’approvisionne à SAMAKONI et en COTE D’IVOIRE. Il effectue ses ventes au comptant.
Mr BROULAYE espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour  subvenir aux besoins de la famille, rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
BROULAYE was born in December 1979 in SAMAKONI, Cercle de KOLONDIEBA, a prefecture in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. He is 35 years old and resides in SAMAKONI in a traditional family with three wives and five children. Early on, he became interested in revenue-generating work, especially the buying and selling of cattle. He makes his sales in SAMAKONI.  

With a solid four years of experience in this domain, he is collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to increase his business capital in order to satisfy his customer base, which is ever-growing. He is on his third loan. His customer base is composed of men. 

Mr. BROULAYE intends to use his loan to purchase 4 head of cattle. His supplies come from SAMAKONI and from COTE D’IVOIRE. His sales are made in cash. Mr. BROULAYE hopes to make a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used to meet family needs, pay back the loan, and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Ayaovi

texts.fr: Restaurateur de profession, Ayaovi est un homme de 39ans et père de famille. Il exerce son activité dans une boutique et se fait aidé par 02 personnes. Manquant de fonds pour augmenter son stock de poissons, il fait sa quatrième demande à WAGES. Le profit tiré de la vente lui permettra d'assurer l'épanouissement de la famille et de rendre pérenne son activité.
texts.en: A restauranteur by profession, Ayaovi is a 39-year-old man and a father with a family. He operates his business in a store and has the help of two persons. Lacking the funds for increasing his stock of fish, he is requesting his fourth loan from WAGES. The profits generated from the sales will enable him to ensure his family thrives and to make his business sustainable.

loans.name: Lilian Lifwede's Group

texts.en:
Lilian has a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof in Induro village, Vihiga County, Kenya. Lilian has 5 sons and 1 daughter. Induro's inhabitants collect their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Induro’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by drinking unsafe water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Induro village, 85 households will benefit from having access to safe water through the dispenser. Lilian has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine and encouraging the community to always treat their water in order to keep themselves and their families healthy. There are three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Rodah, Judith and Rose.

Induro village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the chlorine dispensers in the area. Lilian believes that with regular dispenser use, there will be no more suffering from waterborne diseases. “We must arise and fight water-borne diseases”, says Lilian. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe for drinking. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to ensure that Lilian’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Jamin Kibisu's Group

texts.en:
Jamin is 60 years old and has 6 children. Jamin lives in Busakale village, Vihiga County, Kenya. Busakale village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Jamin and his family may fall sick at any time and become unable to work or attend school.

Though Jamin is a subsistence farmer, he has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Jamin and other promoters in his community, including Mary, Miriam, Elphas and Julia, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Jamin will encourage the community to use the dispenser for treating their household water and will also be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Jamin wants to be a promoter because he loves his community and cares about his neighbors' health. Jamin believes that the dispenser will kills germs and prevent the waterborne diseases that have plagued his community for many years.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Jamin’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Hildah Isagi's Group

texts.en:
Hilda is 28 years old and is a mother of 6. Hilda lives in Musiega village, Vihiga County, Kenya. Musiega village community stands vulnerable to water-borne diseases as they do not have a piped water supply. The community collect their water from a protected spring and this water is easily contaminated with bacteria and other pathogens, meaning that Hilda and her family may fall sick at any time and become unable to work.

Hilda works as a shop-keeper but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Hilda and two other promoters in her community, James and Fredrick, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Hilda will encourage the community to treat their water using the dispenser and will also be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine whenever the tank runs low. Hilda wants to be the promoter because she loves helping others and she believes that the dispenser will prevent water-borne diseases and allow the community to have good health.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe for drinking. The sale of carbon credits to individuals and organizations wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to ensure that Hilda’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine dispensers to treat their drinking water

This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Wamuhira’s inhabitants fall sick and unable to regularly attend work or school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Wamuhira, 38 households will benefit from the dispenser by having access to safe water. Violet has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine and encouraging the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. There are two other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Mary and Amina. 

Wamuhira village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Violet believes that the dispenser will prevents waterborne diseases and kill germs. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Violet’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine dispensers to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Bienvenida

texts.en: Due to financial hardships, Bienvenida aims to improve her small variety store to increase her income. She is 52 years old and has two adult-aged children. She plans to increase her product offerings but she has inadequate capital. In this regard, she is asking for a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy additional stocks of soft drinks, snack foods, assorted candies, noodles, canned goods, beverages, and seasonings to sell. Through this loan, she believes that she will be able to improve her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of soft drinks, snack foods, assorted candies, noodles, canned goods, beverages, and seasonings to sell.

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie is 27 years old and single. She has a mobile money transfer business and also sells mobile phone accessories. She has one child and she supports one person in her family. She has been in this business for three years and right now her monthly income is KES 20,000.

She will be using this loan to increase the money float in her mobile money transfer business. She will also use part of the loan amount to buy mobile phone accessories such as chargers, batteries and phone covers. She will use the anticipated income to expand her business.

This is her third loan term from VisionFund Kenya and she has paid her previous loans successfully. In the future she hopes to be successful in her business.

loans.use: To buy phone accessories and also boost mobile money transfer business

loans.name: Gorretti

texts.en: Gorretti used the previous loan to buy pharmaceutical drugs to sell. She has managed to utilize the proceeds from both the drug shop and the motorcycle to look after her child, being the sole income earner in her family. Her personal goal is buying a car for easy movement from one place to another, even if she is challenged by limited capital. Gorretti intends to use the loan to buy more pharmaceutical drugs to sell.

loans.use: to buy more pharmaceutical drugs to sell.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John, a 46-year-old father of four from Thika, has a business as a mixed-crop farmer. He is married to Ann, who helps him in farming. He earns a monthly income of KES 18,000, which he uses to support himself and his family. 

This marks his fourth loan term with VisionFund Kenya. With the loan he has applied for from VisionFund Kenya, he will be able to purchase poultry feed and purchase one pig for rearing. Additional income created will allow him to improve the standard of living for his family. In the future, John would like to expand his farming to become a large-scale farmer. 

He hopes to educate all his children to the college level.

loans.use: to purchase poultry feed and purchase one pig for rearing

loans.name: Philis Muhonja's Group

texts.en:
Philis has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser in Navohi village, Vihiga County, Kenya. Philis is a hardworking member of the community with 6 children. Philis lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.


Navohi village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Philis and the other 30 households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 


Philis has volunteered to be the chlorine dispenser promoter because she wants to encourage the community to use the dispenser. Philis will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine whenever the tank runs low. Philis has also volunteered to be the promoter because the community members perceive her as informative and she enjoys helping them. She particularly wants to help children in the community, who she knows are always the most affected by water-borne diseases. There are also four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Leah, Violet, Pamela and Margret.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe for drinking. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Philis’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Anne Iragosa's Group

texts.en:
Anne is 48 years old, has 4 children and lives in Enanga village in Vihiga, Kenya. Enanga village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a river. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases. This means that Anne and her family may fall sick and become unable to work and/or her children may not be able to regularly attend school.

Anne works as a commercial farmer but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Anne and other promoters in her community including: Sarah, Margret, Nancy and Tafroza need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Anne will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Anne wants to be a promoter because she wants to assist her community to ensure they do away with water-borne diseases. Anne believes that the dispenser will treat water to prevent water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Anne’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Benkan est un regroupement de femmes de Hamdallaye qui  vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans et ont au moins 5 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, des Habits, Produits cosmétiques, Tissus, Bois de chauffage, Plastique et divers Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso pour la première fois. 
Maichatou qui est un membre du groupe Benkan assise au bout et à droite, est une vendeuse des Habits et tissus. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des Habits, de tissus et des pagnes de plusieurs qualités. Elle se procure de ces articles à Koutiala et les vend à la maison et au marché à une clientèle diverse. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Benkan comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 95.000CFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Maichatou compte réaliser  105.000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce.
texts.en:
Benkan is a group of women from Hamdallaye who live in large traditional families with their husbands, children, and other relatives. The women average 39 years of age and have least 5 children. This group of women does commerce in a variety of goods, such as clothing, cosmetic products, cloth, firewood, plasticware, and more. To expand their businesses, the group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program for the first time. 

Maichatou, who is a member of the group Benkan, is the one sitting at the end at the right in the photo. She is a vendor of clothing and fabrics. She intends to use her loan to purchase some clothing, fabrics, and several grades of 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa). She procures these items in Koutiala and sells them to a diverse customer base at the house and at the market. 

While the other members of the group Benkan plan on making an average profit of 95,000 francs CFA over the course of this loan cycle, Ms. Maichatou plans on making 105,000 francs.

In addition to paying back these loans, the women use part of the revenues to cope with personal expenses and to increase their business capital.

loans.use: to purchase clothing

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by drinking unsafe water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Igakala village, 33 households will benefit from having access to safe water through the dispenser. Tabitha has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine whenever the tank runs low and encouraging the community to treat their water in order to keep themselves and their families healthy. Igakala village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers in the area. Tabitha believes that the dispenser will prevent water-borne diseases. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits.
