loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr: Jeune homme de 29ans, Kodjo est marié et n'a pas d'enfants en charge. Pour jouer son rôle de père de famille, il a démarré la vente des boissons dans une boutique à ses clients. Manquant de fonds pour acheter des boissons en quantité, il fait sa toute première demande à WAGES. L’intérêt tiré de la vente lui permettra d'agrandir son stock et de mieux prendre en charge sa famille. Il a une ancienneté de 04ans dans l'activité.
texts.en: A young man of 29, Kodjo is married and has no children to support. To fulfill the role of father of a family, he started off selling beverages in a store. Lacking the funds to purchase beverages in quantity, he is taking out his very first loan from WAGES. The [profits] made from the sales will enable him to expand his stock and to take better care of his family. He has four years of seniority in this business.

loans.use: to purchase beverages and other products

loans.name: Mary Wambui's Group

texts.en:
In Ludondo village, Vihiga County, Kenya, Mary has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Mary is a friendly, goal oriented, reliable and well-known member of the community with 2 children. Mary lives with her family in a house made up of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.

Ludondo village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Mary’s family and other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Mary has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and will also refill the dispenser with chlorine whenever the tank runs low. Mary volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help her community fight water-borne diseases. She believes that regular chlorine dispenser use will result in good health and prosperity within the community. There are three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Jane, Beatrice and Janet. 

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mary’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Everlyne Aseyo's Group

texts.en:
Everlyne lives in Kitulu village, Vihiga County, Kenya and is 23 years old. Kitulu village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This means that Everlyne and her family or any other member of the community may fall sick and become unable to work at any time as their water is easily contaminated with bacteria and other pathogens that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases.

Everlyne works as a boda boda operator (motorcycle taxi) but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Everlyne and other promoters in her community, including Jaika, Ernest, Betty and Joyce, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Everlyne will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser and will also be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Everlyne wants to be the promoter because she would like to assist her community to prevent water-borne diseases.  Everlyne believes that through high chlorine dispenser adoption, her community will stay healthy and safe from water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Everlyne’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine dispensers to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Ruth Nyamko's Group

texts.en:
Ruth has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser in Mayimba village, Vihiga County, Kenya. Ruth is a hardworking, trustworthy and a well-known member of the community with 6 children. Ruth lives with her family in a house made up of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.

Mayimba village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water at the point of collection to make it safe to drink. Ruth’s family and other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Ruth has volunteered to be the promoter and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine whenever necessary and will also encourage the community to use the dispenser. Ruth volunteered to be the promoter because she values good health and want to help her community stay away from water-borne diseases. Ruth believes that as a former teacher, she will have an easy time educating the community on the benefits of treating water with the chlorine from the dispenser. There are also three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Flora, Janet and Rose.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe for drinking. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Ruth’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Foster Munayi's Group

texts.en:
Foster, a friendly, reliable and well-liked member of the community with 7 children, has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser in Nyira village, Vihiga County, Kenya. Foster lives with his family in a house made up of concrete walls, concrete floor and iron roof. 

Nyira village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water at the point of collection to make it safe for drinking. Foster’s family and other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Foster has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill the dispenser with chlorine whenever the tank runs low. Foster volunteered to be the promoter because he wants to help his community drink safe water. Foster believes that regular chlorine dispenser use will prevent waterborne diseases in the community. There are three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Josephine, Jesca and Phanice.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Foster’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Mikafumawu

texts.fr: Veuve et mère de famille, cette dame opère dans la restauration depuis 2002 et le fait de façon ambulante. Pour mieux répondre aux besoins des clients, Mikafumawu fait sa troisième demande dans notre institution WAGES pour acheter des ingrédients entrant dans la préparation de la nourriture. Elle espère avoir un mini restaurant pour vendre afin d'éviter de se promener et de mieux se prendre en charge.
texts.en: A widow and mother of a family, this woman has been working in the food service business going door to door since 2002. To respond better to customer needs, Mikafumawu is taking out her third loan from our microfinance institution WAGES to purchase some ingredients for making food. She hopes to have a min-restaurant for her sales in order to avoid walking and to support herself better.

loans.use: to purchase food items

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy is 52 years old, married, and has three children. She is a resident of Talic, Oroquieta City, Philippines. She earns a living through rice retailing at the market and sometimes sells it to the neighboring places near home. With the money she generated from her retailing, she is able to support the needs of her family. 

She has been a member of PMPC for two years and enjoys the privileges and services being a member of the cooperative. Now, she is applying for a loan of PHP 3,000 to buy ingredients for snack vending. This is her new business as she wants to earn additional income.

Daisy deeply wishes to maintain a member in good standing with PMPC.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for snack vending

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en: Vilma engages in buying and reselling of frozen foods within her local community. She is 43 years old and has three school-aged children. Due to the high cost of school fees, she aims to improve her business in order to help her husband in financing the education of her children. To improve her business, she is asking for a loan of 8,000 PHP to buy more stocks of frozen foods like hot dogs, cured sausages, cured pork and fish to sell. Through patience and hard work, she believes that she will be able to make her business profitable.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of frozen foods like hot dogs, cured sausages, cured pork and fish to sell.

loans.name: Celestino

texts.es:
Celestino tiene 70 años de edad, vive en el cantón, está acompañado y su esposa se dedica al trabajo doméstico, tiene una hija y es la única que depende de él.

Desde muy pequeño el señor Celestino se dedica al trabajo de agricultor, él tiene cuatro vacas de las cuales obtiene leche y vende sus derivados, actualmente la mayoría de sus ingresos proviene de un rancho que tiene en la playa en el cual hace 3 años ha iniciado en este rubro, él participa en el comité de turismo de su comunidad, pues están realizando proyectos para impulsar esta actividad de turismo en la zona, el rancho es atendido por él y su esposa y está abierto al público solo los fines de semana desde las 7:00 de la mañana en adelante.

Él tiene mucha experiencia en el área de alimentos, ya que trabajó durante muchos años en Estados Unidos en un restaurante.

El préstamo que está solicitando a CrediCampo lo necesita para la compra de mesas y sillas, pues tiene muy pocas, además quiere construirle una protección a la orilla del rancho para que no entre más arena durante las mareas altas y de esta manera ya no le siga afectando su negocio.

Su sueño es que a través el comité de turismo pueda mejorar la publicidad de esta playa, para que la afluencia de personas no solo sea los fines de semana, sino abrir de lunes a viernes y con esto mejorar sus ventas y las ventas de las demás personas que poseen sus negocios en la zona.
texts.en:
Celestino is 70 years old, married and lives in the canton. His wife does the housework. He has a daughter and she solely dependent on him. Since he was very young, Celestino worked in agriculture. He has four cows from which he gets milk and sells their by-products. Currently, the majority of his income comes from a beach food shack which he started in this area three years ago. He participates on the tourism committee in his community and is working on projects to increase tourism in this area. He and his wife run the food shack, and it is only open to the public on the weekends after 7:00 in the morning. He has a lot of experience in food service as he worked at a restaurant for many years in the United States. 

He applied for a loan with CrediCampo to buy tables and chairs since he has very few. He also wants to build a shore barrier for the food shack so that sand cannot come in during high tide and continue to affect his business. 

His dream is to use the tourism committee to increase publicity for the beach so that the influx of people is not only limited to the weekends so he can be open Monday through Friday. This will improve his sales and the sales of the other people who have businesses in this region.

loans.use: to buy chairs and tables for the food shack.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 35-year-old man, married to Millicent and supporting a family of seven. He takes care of his four children and two orphans. He operates a food stall by the roadside on the outskirts of Bomet town in Kenya. He has been selling food for the last six years with a monthly income of KES 18,000. He learned about VisionFund from a neighbor.

John has been advanced a second loan of KES 30,000 after successfully paying off the first one. He intends to put up a food stall using the funds advanced. He will use the proceeds to provide the family's basic needs. He also intends to build a perimeter wall around his compound

loans.use: to build a food stall

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy materials, lining and sewing threads

loans.name: Phanice Mulonga's Group

Phanice is a friendly, goal oriented, hardworking, reliable, trustworthy and a well-known member of the community with 7 children. Phanice lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.

Bugamangi village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Phanice and 65 other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Phanice has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and will also be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine when the tank runs low. Phanice volunteered to be the promoter because she is willing to serve the community in the fight against water-borne diseases. She believes that chlorine dispensers will greatly contribute to her community’s wellbeing and prosperity. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Noah, Jescah, Bendeta and Violet.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Phanice’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Grace Iminza's Group

Shandoro village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases meaning that Grace, her family and any member of Shandoro village community may fall sick at any time and become unable to work or attend school.

Grace is a shop-keeper but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Grace and other promoters in her community including Daniel, Priscillah and Emily need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Grace will encourage the community to treat their water using the dispenser and will refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Grace wants to be the promoter because she is willing to serve her community. Grace believes that treating water through the chlorine dispenser will kill bacteria and other pathogens to make their water safe for drinking. Through regular dispenser use, Grace believes her community will stay away from water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Grace’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

Madzuu village community collects their household water from a protected spring since the village does not have a piped water supply. Grace is 54 years old, has 4 children and lives in Kigogo village in Vihiga County, Kenya. Kigogo village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases meaning that Grace and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Manish

texts.en:
Manish is the proprietor of MLGS Telecom. MLGS Telecom is the rural distributor of Solar lighting, Water purifier and Airtel Mobile Connections.
Manish operates in the area where only 40% of the houses are electrified.  He serves the rural households to improve their standards of living. Manish has 15 years of experience in serving the rural area. He has a good sales network and reachability in his area.

MLGS Telecom is now focusing on providing solar lighting to rural people. MLGS Telecom would like to help rural people improve their standard of living by supplying solar home lighting solutions. Manish is aiming to light 1200 houses in his area.  He wants to extend the loan to the rural poor to buy solar home lighting systems and help them to improve their standard of living.

Manish’s vision is to serve the rural household to get access to lighting and safe drinking water by partnering with companies like Barefoot Power.

loans.use: to buy and sell Barefoot Power's solar lighting product

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe TIESSIRI  sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  27ans, 2enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à FAKOLA, une des sous-préfectures de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités à tout moment. Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution et compte bien le rembourser.
Mme MARAMOU (1ère sur la photo de la droite  à la gauche) compte acheter avec son prêt 2 sacs d’atiéke et 10kg de viande pour ses activités de restauration. Elle vend quotidiennement au marché de FAKOLA et est très sollicitée surtout le jour de foire.Elle s’approvisionne à FAKOLA. Elle vend au comptant  à une clientèle mixte.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22 000FCFA.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the group TIESSIRI are married women, who average 27 years of age and two children each, all living in polygamous families in FAKOLA, a sub-prefecture in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their work anytime soon. They are on their first loan with the institution and do intend to pay it back. 

Ms. MARAMOU (first person at the right in the photo) intends to use her loan to purchase 2 sacks of atiéké [fermented cassava couscous] and 10 kg of meat for her restaurant business. Each day, she makes her sales at the FAKOLA market and is much in demand, especially during fairs. She gets her supplies in FAKOLA. 

She accepts cash from a mixed customer base. She plans on making an average monthly profit of 22,000 francs CFA. This profit will enable her to pay back the loan and also to help out her husband in covering day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to purchase the ingredients for her restaurant

loans.name: Joannes

texts.en:
Joannes is a 43-year-old man from Usenge. He is married to Susan and they have a two-year-old child.

He sells general goods, especially kitchenware, a business he has done for the past six years, earning an income of KES 20,000 monthly. He is taking a second loan of KES 25,000 with VisionFund Kenya to use in purchasing more cartons of general goods. He plans to use the profits to improve the lives of his family members.

His dream is to own a mega general store.

loans.use: To purchase more general goods like knives, plastic cups, washing basins and other utensils.

loans.name: Grace Jolly

texts.en: Grace Jolly used the previous loan to buy building materials such as cement, sand and bricks for the construction of her house. Having the determination to educate her children, she is doing all that she can to ensure that her children go to school. Limited capital is the challenge she faces. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Tanny Ixmucane

texts.es:
Tanny es una joven emprendedora de 19 años de edad, está soltera y actualmente está estudiando segundo año de bachillerato, ella vive con sus padres y una hermana, sus padres tienen alquiler de habitaciones y la hermana una sala de belleza de la cual ella es socia. 

Esta joven tiene el negocio de sala de belleza junto a su hermana desde hace 3 años, ellas con mucha lucha y sacrificio han logrado que el negocio vaya creciendo, Tanny aprendió este trabajo por su hermana  quien estudió cosmetología, entonces ellas  tuvieron la idea de que juntas pusieran el negocio el cual lo tienen en su casa de habitación. 

El préstamo que está solicitando a CrediCampo, lo necesita para comprar dos sillas de peluquero, las cuales se las están vendiendo baratas, y ya que el negocio sigue adquiriendo más clientes, Tanny ve necesaria la compra de dichas sillas y además comprarán más productos relacionados con la cosmetología. 

Para un futuro, Tanny planea que el negocio siga en ascenso para seguir trabajando junto a su hermana, montar otro negocio en un lugar con mayor afluencia de personas para generar más ingresos, además sueña con terminar sus estudios académicos y convertirse en una profesional graduada de la universidad, formar su familia en un futuro no muy lejano y no dejar de lado el negocio.
texts.en:
Tanny is a young enterprising 19 year old girl. She is currently in her second year of college. She lives with her parents and her sister. Her parents rent rooms and her sister has a beauty salon in which she is a partner. This girl has had the business of a beauty salon with her sister for 3 years, and they have worked hard to expand the business. Tanny learned this work from her sister who studied cosmetology, and so they had the idea of starting a business together in one of the rooms of their house.
She is requesting a loan from CrediCampo to buy two salon chairs that she can get at a cheaper price. Due to the increase of customers Tanny finds it necessary to buy such chairs and also they will buy more products related to cosmetology.
In the future Tanny plans to keep expanding this business and keep on working with her sister and open another business in a place with more influx of people in order to earn more income. She also dreams of finishing her academic studies and become a professional graduate from a university, form a family in the near future, and keep on working in her business.

loans.use: To buy beauty salon chairs and also more products related to cosmetology.

loans.name: Carolyne Okema's Group

texts.en:
Carolyne lives with her family that includes four children in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and an iron roof in Lugango village, Vihiga County, Kenya. The community of Lugango village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Lugango’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.
	
A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by drinking unsafe water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Lugango village, 63 households will benefit from having access to safe water through the dispenser. Carolyne has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine and encouraging the whole community to treat their water in order to keep themselves and their families safe and healthy. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Jackline, Beatrice, Hesbon and Javan.

Lugango village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers in the area. Carolyne believes that regular chlorine dispenser use will keep water-borne diseases at bay. Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Carolyne’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

texts.en:
In Busamo village, Vihiga County, Kenya, Linet has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Linet is a hardworking and trustworthy member of the community with 5 children. Linet lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.

Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water at the point of collection to make it safe to drink. Linet’s family and other 90 households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Linet has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill the dispenser with chlorine when the tank runs low. Linet volunteered to be the promoter because she greatly values her community’s health and wants to work towards that by being at the forefront. Linet believes that through chlorine dispenser adoption, her community will preserve trees in the area and achieve improved health. loans.name: Kokadje Group

texts.fr:
Kokadje est un regroupement de femmes de Hamdallaye qui se connaissent bien et qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 54 ans et ont au moins 8enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, des Savons, Tissus, Bois de chauffage, Huile, déodorants, Produits cosmétiques et divers.Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur vingt-deuxième prêt de groupe.
Awa, troisième personne de la gauche vers la droite, est une vendeuse de Savons, Huiles, déodorants etc. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter du savon, déodorants, huile en quantité. Elle se procure de ses articles à Koutiala et les vend à la maison et au marché à une clientèle diverse. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Kokadje comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 90 000CFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Awa compte réaliser  110.000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en: Kokadje is a group of women from Hamdallaye who know each other well and who live in large traditional families with their husbands, childrens, and other relatives. They are on average 54 years old and have at least 8 children. This group of women sells miscellaneous items, such as soaps, fabric, firewood, oil, deodorant, cosmetic products, etc. In order to increase the level of their businesses, the members decided to integrate Soro Yiriwaso’s loan program. They are on their twenty-first group loan. Awa, third person from the left, sells soaps, oils, deodorant, etc. She plans to use her loan to buy soap, deodorant, and oil in bulk. She stocks up on the items in Koutiala and sells them from home or at the market to a diverse clientele. While the other Kokadje group members each plan to make an average of 90,000 FCFA a month in profits, Mrs. Awa plans to make 110,000 FCFA. Other than repaying her loans, she uses a part of her profit on personal expenses and to increase her business funds. She hopes to see this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso get reinforced so that reserves don’t run out.

loans.use: to buy miscellaneous items

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy, a 41-year-old single mother of two from Thika, earns a living for her family by operating a retail shop. She has been unable to keep her shop fully stocked due to lack of investment capital. 

Her business is only marginally sustainable because she is unable to expand it. Her goal is to fully stock her store in order to attract more customers and increase her profits. Nancy is requesting a loan from VisionFund Kenya in order to stock her shop with rice, sugar, washing detergents, maize meal, cooking oil, and flour. With the additional income she will earn from this improvement, she will be able to improve the living conditions for her family and support the education of her two children. 

In the future, Nancy plans to continue to invest in her business and to eventually operate a larger wholesale store.

loans.use: to stock her shop with rice, sugar, washing detergents, maize meal, cooking oil, and flour

loans.name: Marie Jean

texts.en:
Marie Jean is 45 years old, and married with four children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Marie Jean is borrowing 20,000 PHP through NWTF in order to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Marie Jean has been raising pigs for three years and also earns additional income from raising chickens.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream of saving enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Reyna De La Paz

texts.es:
Reyna de 54 años de edad, estudió hasta tercer grado en el pueblo del cantón donde vive, está acompañada; su compañero de vida trabaja con ganado bovino y también en la agricultura, tienen cuatro hijos de los que solo dos viven en casa con ellos, uno reside en Estados Unidos, el otro tiene su propio hogar, los dos que viven con ellos trabajan y aportan economicamente al hogar.

Ella trabaja con ganado bovino, desde hace mucho tiempo, además, se dedica a la agricultura, en la que se traslada a una distancia de 2km desde su casa, a pie o en carreta, en esto se involucra su esposo y un nieto.

El préstamo lo necesitará para comprar un ternero, considera, que eso le mejorará; porque aumentará las cabezas de ganado y también se prepara para una necesidad en un futuro, porque con los ingresos extra, podrá ahorrar.

Sus sueños son poder crecer con el numero de animales y poder tener ganado lechero, que le pueda dar mas sustento alimenticio para su familia. espera que a sus hijos no les falte el trabajo y que tengan salud para que puedan sostener a su familia, piensa ampliar su negocio incluyendo peliguey, además, con ganado lechero; pero lo logrará con la ayuda de su hija que reside en Estados Unidos y los préstamos que Credicampo que le otorgue.
texts.en:
Reyna is 54 years old and studied up to third grade in the town where she lives. Reyna has a partner who works with cattle and in farming. They couple has four children: two still live at home while one lives in the US and the other has his own home now. The two children still living at home work and support the household financially.

Reyna has been working with cattle for a long time and, in addition, she works in farming. She travels two kilometres - by foot or on a wagon - to arrive at her work,  where her husband and one grandson also work.

Reyna needs this loan in order to buy a calf. She thinks this will help her as she will have more cattle and she is preparing for a rainy day. With more income, she can save up some money.

Reyna's dreams are to increase her number of animals and to have dairy cattle. With this she can support the family with more food. Reyna hopes that her children always have work and their health so that they can support the family. Reyna is thinking of expanding her business with dairy cattle and more. She does this with help from her daughter - who lives in the US - and from the loans granted by "CrediCampo".

loans.use: to buy a calf.

loans.name: Felister Mulonga's Group

texts.en:
Felister lives in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof in Madidi village, Vihiga County, Kenya, with her family which includes 4 children. The community of Madidi village collects their drinking water from a flowing stream because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Madidi’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser program offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by drinking unsafe water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans and then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Madidi village, 50 households will benefit from having access to safe water through the chlorine dispenser. Felister has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter and will be responsible for refilling the dispenser with chlorine and encouraging the whole community to treat their water in order to keep themselves and their families safe and healthy. There is one other volunteer promoter from the surrounding community who is part of this group loan, named Florence.

Madidi village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers in the area. Felister believes that the dispenser will greatly contribute to improved community health. Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Felister’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Kabessizi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe KABESSIZI sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  27ans, 2 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à FAKOLA, une des sous -préfectures de la 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités à tout moment. Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution et compte bien le rembourser.
Mme AICHA  (1ère sur la photo de la droite  à la gauche) fait de la restauration. Elle compte acheter avec son prêt 2 sacs de riz et 2 colis de condiments. Elle vend quotidiennement à FAKOLA et est très sollicitée surtout le jour de foire. Elle s’approvisionne à FAKOLA. Elle vend au comptant  à une clientèle mixte.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 21000FCFA.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the group KABESSIZI are married women, who average 27 years of age and two children each, all living in polygamous families in FAKOLA, a sub-prefecture in the 3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali. 

The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their work at any time. They are on their first loan with the institution and do intend to pay it back. 

Ms. AICHA (first person at the right in the photo) is in the restaurant business. She intends to use her loan to purchase 2 sacks of rice and 2 packages of condiments. Each day, she makes her sales in FAKOLA and is much in demand, especially during fairs. She gets her supplies in FAKOLA. 

She accepts cash from a mixed customer base. She plans on making an average monthly profit of 21,000 francs CFA. This profit will enable her to pay back the loan and also to help out her husband in covering day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to purchase the ingredients for her restaurant

loans.name: Kafui

texts.fr: Revendeuse de pagnes, de parfums et autres produits dans sa boutique, Kafui se bat chaque fois pour assurer le bien - être de la famille. Pour agrandir son stock et satisfaire les besoins des clients, elle sollicite un premier crédit pour atteindre son objectif. Son souhait est d'agrandir son stock et assurer une bonne éducation à ses enfants. Elle a pour conjoint un gendarme et mère de 02 enfants(05 et 01an). Seul l'ainé est scolarisé. Kafui quant à elle a une ancienneté de 09ans dans l'activité et âgée de 30ans.
texts.en: A seller of pagnes (brightly colored cloths), perfume, and other products in her shop, Kafui continually fights for the well being of her family. To grow her stock and to satisfy the needs of her customers, she is seeking her first loan to reach her goal. Her wish is to increase her stock and ensure a good education for her children. Her husband is a police officer, and she is a mother of two (ages 5 and 1). Only the eldest attends school. Kafui has been in her business for 9 years, and she is 30 years old.

loans.use: to buy pagnes, perfume and other products

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily, a married mother of three from Embu, has a business as a mixed-crop farmer. She has been in the farming business for the past 10 years. She earns a monthly income of KES 15,000, which she uses to support her family. 

This marks her first loan term with VisionFund Kenya after she was introduced by an existing client. With the loan she has applied for she will be able to purchase seedlings and fertilizers for her farm. The additional income created will allow her to improve the standard of living for her family and use the remaining amount for the education for her children. In the future, Emily would like to expand her farming land. 

She hopes to become a prominent farmer in Embu.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizers for her farm

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
To have an additional source of income, Virginia engages in direct selling of Avon, Boardwalk, and Personal Collection products within her community. She is 60 years old and has four adult-age children. She aims to acquire more stocks of the mentioned products to sell, but she doesn't have enough capital. For this reason, she is asking for a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy additional stocks of Avon, Boardwalk and Personal Collection products to sell. 

Being a kind and diligent mother, she believes that she will be able to improve the business.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of Avon, Boardwalk, and Personal Collection products to sell.

loans.name: Nelson Eduardo

texts.es:
Nelson de 53 años de edad, esta acompañada convive con su esposa y sus tres  hijos, estudio hasta sexto grado. Se levanta a las 5:00 a.m. Junto a su esposa e hijos que le apoyan en la actividades agrícolas y en el ordeño de los animales. 

 Nelson junto a su esposa se dedican a la agricultura, oficio que aprendió de sus padres;  durante la mañana mientras su esposa se dedica a los oficios domésticos y en la tarde él cuida las vacas.


El préstamo que esta solicitando, es para comprar dos  vacas que necesita para incrementar la producción de leche, que ocupa para la elaboración de queso, crema que ofrece en su domicilio.

Nelson planea que con los ingresos que obtiene de la venta de lácteos,  la siembra, podrá comprar un terreno para pastar sus animales.
texts.en:
Nelson is 53 years old and in a common-law relationship. He lives with his wife and three children. Nelson has a sixth grade education. Nelson wakes up at 5:00 A.M. before he, his wife, and his children take care of the farm duties and the milking of the animals.

Nelson learned this trade from his parents. He and his wife work together – she takes care of the household chores in the mornings and he looks after the cows in the afternoons.

The loan he is requesting will be used to buy two cows that are needed to increase milk production. The milk will be used to make cheese and cream that will be sold from his home. Nelson plans to use the income that he earns from selling dairy products and farming for buying a plot of land where his animals can graze.

loans.use: to buy two dairy cows.

loans.name: James' Group

texts.en:
James is 32 years old, has 1 child and lives in Matagalu village in Vihiga County, Kenya. Matagalu village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that James and his family may fall sick at any time and become unable to work or attend school.

James is a shop-keeper but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. James and other promoters in his community, including Josephat, Catherine, Esther and Florah, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. James will encourage the community to treat their water using the dispenser and will refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. James wants to be the promoter because he loves working for the community and wants to help them access safe water. James believes that regular chlorine dispenser use will result in improved community health.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that James’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community

loans.name: Debra Muhonja's Group

texts.en:
In Chanzuvu village, Vihiga County, Kenya, Debra has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Debra is a friendly member of the community with 5 children. Debra lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.

Chanzuvu village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Debra’s family and 60 other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Debra has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. Debra volunteered to be the promoter because she wants to help her community drink treated water. Debra believes that chlorine will kill germs and prevent water-borne diseases. Three other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities form part of this group loan: Dorothy, Herman and Phemines.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Debra’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Tafrosa Kageha's Group

texts.en:
Tafrosa lives in Nyabera village in Vihiga County, Kenya. Tafrosa is 47 years old and has 6 children. Nyabera village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Tafrosa and her family may fall sick at any time and become unable to work or attend school.

Tafrosa works as a taxi operator but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Tafrosa and other promoters in her community, including Janet, Pamela and Beatrice, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Tafrosa will encourage the community to treat their water using the dispenser and will refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Tafrosa wants to be the promoter because she is a hard-working and well-liked member of the community. Tafrosa believes that regular chlorine dispenser use will greatly contribute towards eradication of water-borne diseases.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Tafrosa’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Jackline Amadadi's Group

texts.en:
Jackline is 26 years old, has 1 child and lives in Magui village in Vihiga County, Kenya. Magui village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Jackline and her family may fall sick at any time and become unable to work or attend school.

Jackline sells groceries but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Jackline and other promoters in her community, including Judith, John, Roselyn and Samwel, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Jackline will encourage the community to treat their water using the dispenser and will refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Jackline wants to be the promoter because she believes that she is well-known and well-liked in her community, and she believes that through regular chlorine dispenser use, her community will be able to avoid water-borne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Jackline’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To improve health and productivity by increasing access to safe drinking water through chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Elisham Meso's Group

texts.en:
In Mulele village, Vihiga County, Kenya, Elisham has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Elisham is friendly, hardworking, reliable and a well-known member of the community with 5 children. Elisham lives with his family in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.

Mulele village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water at the point of collection to make it safe to drink. Elisham’s family and 45 other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Elisham has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill the dispenser with chlorine when the tank runs low. Elisham volunteered to be the promoter because he wants to help his people live a healthy life. Elisham believes that through regular chlorine dispenser use, his community will become less sick and hence save more money for development. There are two other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Titus and Susan.

Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Elisham’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Christine Inyangara's Group

texts.en:
In Kitulu/Burudi village in Vihiga County, Kenya, Christine has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Christine is friendly, hardworking, reliable and a well-known member of the community with 5 children. Christine lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, dirt floor and iron roof.

Kitulu/Burudi village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water at the point of collection to make it safe to drink. Christine’s family and 67 other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Christine has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill the dispenser with chlorine when the tank runs low. Christine volunteered to be the promoter because she is trustworthy and always available to serve her community. Christine believes that chlorine dispenser use will kill germs and prevent water-borne diseases. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Elizabeth, Nancy, Christine and Harun.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Christine’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To provide communities with free access to chlorine to treat their drinking water

loans.name: Irene Odindo's Group

texts.en:
In Kezege village, Vihiga County, Kenya, Irene has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program. Irene is friendly, reliable, trustworthy and a well-liked member of the community with 4 children. Irene lives with her family in a house made of mud walls, concrete floor and iron roof.

Kezege village does not have a piped water supply so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Irene’s family and 70 other households using the local water sources need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Irene has volunteered to be the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill the dispenser with chlorine when the tank runs low. Irene volunteered to be the promoter because her community likes her and she believes they will listen to her. Irene believes that through chlorine dispenser adoption, her community will prevent water-borne diseases. There are two other volunteer promoters from the surrounding communities who are part of this group loan: Jasron and David.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community through the sale of carbon credits. Using chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. Revenues from the sale of carbon credits to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce world carbon footprint will be used to repay Kiva lenders and to make sure that Irene’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To allow the community to treat their water to make it safe to drink using chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Soutoura est un regroupement de femmes de Hamdallaye qui vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et autres parents. Elles ont en moyenne 47 ans et ont au moins 4 enfants.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers tels que, Légumes, fruits et divers.Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso.Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe.
Fanta  1 ère assise de la gauche vers la droite est une vendeuse de fruits et légumes : Choux, tomates, papayes, de pomme de terre. Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des fruits et légumes de différentes qualités et quantités. Elle se procure de ces articles à Koutiala et les vend à la maison et au marché à une clientèle diverse. 
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Soutoura comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 110 000CFA  chacune au  cours de ce cycle Mme Fanta  compte réaliser  120 000FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utilisent une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses personnelles et augmenter son fonds de commerce. 
Elles souhaitent voir renforcer ce partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour que les stocks ne soient pas rares.
texts.en:
Soutoura is a group of women from Hamdallaye who know each other well and who live in large traditional families with their husbands, childrens, and other relatives. They are on average 47 years old and have at least 4 children. This group of women sells miscellaneous items, such as vegetables, fruits, and other products. In order to increase the level of their businesses, the members decided to integrate Soro Yiriwaso’s loan program. They are on their second group loan. 

Fanta, on the left, sells fruits and vegetables: cabbage, tomatoes, papayas, potatoes. She plans to use her loan to buy fruits and vegetables of different quality and in different quantities. She stocks up on the products in Koutiala and sells them from home or at the market to a diverse clientele. While the other Kokadje group members each plan to make an average of 110,000 FCFA a month in profits, Mrs. Awa plans to make 120,000 FCFA. Other than repaying her loans, she uses a part of her profit on personal expenses and to increase her business funds. She hopes to see this partnership with Soro Yiriwaso get reinforced so that reserves don’t run out.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Mohbiby

texts.en: Mohbiby was born in 1966. She is the sole provider for her children because her husband died some years ago. Mohbiby has a medical education and works in a local hospital as a nurse. She has been working there for more than 25 years. Mohbiby is one of the best workers. Her colleagues know her as a hardworking woman. Mohbiby’s elder son works in Russia and her smaller son is a schoolboy. She uses her salary to buy food items and clothes for herself and her children. She lives poorly and does not own a fridge. Mohbiby is asking for a loan of 2,500 TJS to buy a fridge for her household. She awaits your support.

loans.use: To buy a fridge for her household

loans.name: Nanita

texts.en:
Nanita, a mother of three children, helps her husband operate their own farm to make a living. For years, the couple has earned well to provide for the family. 

Nanita grows and sell pigs in town. She had planned to improve their piggery in order to send her children to school. 

Recently, she took a new loan from Gata Daku Multi-Purpose Cooperative (GDMPC) to buy feed to have higher returns. 

In the future, Nanita wants to provide a good education for her children and to improve the general living situation of the entire family.

loans.use: to buy feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Consolacion

texts.en:
Consolacion works hard to support her family. Consolacion is married and has a buy and sell charcoal and root crops business in the Philippine. She requested a loan of 11,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional sacks of charcoal to sell. Consolacion has been in this business for the past 20 years. 

Consolacion would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.es:
Wilfredo de 35 años de edad, estudió hasta noveno grado de educacion básica, es acompañado, su compañera se dedica a los oficios domésticos, tienen tres hijos, él trabaja como agente de seguridad en una venta de respuestos de vehículo.

El cliente es agente de seguridad, con su padre aprendio a trabajar en fincas cafetaleras como jornal, cuando tenia 16 años ingreso al ejercito, luego fue policia, tiene mucha experiencia en lo que hace.

El préstamo lo ocupará para la compra de una motocicleta que ocupará para moverse a su trabajo, tambien se transportará a una comunidad a vender sorbetes en sus días libres, actividad que le genera ingresos extra.

A futuro quiere construir una casa, ya que actualmente viven en casa del papá de su compañera de vida, pero ellos sueñan con que un día tendrán su propia casita.
texts.en:
Wilfredo, 35 years old, studied up to ninth grade and has a domestic partner. His common law wife works in domestic chores. They have three children. He works as a security guard in a store of auto parts. The client is a security guard. With his father he learned to work in coffee farms as a daily laborer. When he was 16 years old he joined the army, after that he was a policeman. He has a lot of experience in what he does.
He will use the loan to buy a motorcycle that he will use to drive to his job. Also he will drive to a town to sell sorbets in his days off, an activity that provides extra income for him. In the future he wants to build a house, because currently they live in his partner's father's house; but they dream of a day in which they will have their own little house.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Marvin Antonio

texts.es:
Marvin de 29 años de edad, estudio hasta noveno grado es casado y su pareja se dedica a los oficios domésticos, tiene dos hijos. Él es empleado en una farmacia desde hace 8 años, para trasladarse al trabajo lo hace en bus y en ocasiones en bicicleta, lo cual se tarda 1 hora y su horario es de 8 de la mañana a 5 de la tarde.

Necesita el préstamo, para mejorar la vivienda específicamente arreglar el techo, ventana y puerta y encementar el piso, el crédito le va a beneficiar para darle seguridad y encementado el piso los muebles no pueden deteriorarse

Espera, seguir esforzándose para el estudio de las hijos y en un futuro seguir haciendo mejoras a la vivienda o ampliarla.
texts.en:
Marvin is 29 years old, and he has attended school up to the ninth grade. He is married, and his wife takes care of the house. He has two children. He has been employed by a pharmacy for 8 years.  He goes to work on the bus, and occasionally on a bicycle, which takes one hour. His schedule is from 8 in the morning to 5 in the afternoon.

He needs the loan in order to improve his home; specifically, to repair the roof, window, and door, and cement the floor. The loan will benefit him, providing security—with a cement floor, the furniture won’t deteriorate. 

He hopes to continue striving to educate his children, and in the future he hopes to continue making improvements to his home, or to expand it.

loans.use: to improve his home, specifically, to repair the roof, window, and door, and to cement the floor.

loans.name: Dúo Elizabeth Group

texts.es:
DUO ELIZABETH
Este grupo está formado por doña Ana Patricia, quien es la líder del grupo, tiene 4 hijos, es casada y se dedica a  la venta de ropa típica y sandalias, también vende veladoras y candelas desde hace 7 años, está solicitando este crédito porque necesita ampliar su local que tiene ubicados en el mercado de su localidad, ella vende todos los días y los fines de semana es cuando ella vende un poco más, quiere comprar sandalias de diferentes estilos y números, también quiere comprar ropa típica como, blusas, delantales, y algunos cortes, también quiere comenzar a hacer las candelas aromáticas y necesita material ya que le han pedido mucho de eso y espera que fape le pueda ayudar.
texts.en:
Ana Patricia is part of this group, and she is the group leader.  She has four children and is married.  She sells typical clothing and sandals.  She has also been selling candles for seven years.

She is requesting this loan because she needs to expand her place, which is at the local market.  She sells every day.  The week-ends are when she sells a little more.  She wants to buy different styles and sizes of sandals.  She also wants to buy typical clothing like blouses, aprons, and some skirts.  She also wants to start making scented candles, and she needs material.  She has already received a lot of requests for this.  She hopes that FAPE is able to help her.

loans.use: to buy typical clothing to sell.

loans.name: Flor De Marina

texts.es:
Flor tiene 39 años de edad, tuvo la oportunidad de ir a la universidad y es licenciada en administración de empresas, está casada y su esposo se dedica al comercio, tienen dos hijos que están estudiando y además con Flor viven sus padres. 

Ella tiene un negocio de papelería frente a una escuela, este negocio lo tiene desde hace 4 años, se dedicó a esta actividad porque vive frente a la escuela y vio que podía aprovechar de obtener ingresos para la familia, además tiene un negocio de sastrería y de una tienda que está en la misma casa, en el negocio de la tienda se involucra el esposo, y en el de la sastrería su papá, todo el trabajo que realizan lo hacen diariamente de 7:00 de la mañana hasta las 4:00 de la tarde.

Flor está solicitando este préstamo a CrediCampo, para comprar tres docenas de cada tipo y tamaño de cuadernos y papel bond para surtir  la librería, con lo demás surtirá la tienda con golosinas y sodas, con productos que más demandan los clientes, esto le ayudará a mejorar mucho en el negocio y a no tener pérdidas por no tener disponible lo que el cliente busca. 

Ella espera que con sacrificio y trabajo, vaya a poner un cyber ya que frente a la escuela es muy buena ubicación, de esta forma obtendrá más ingresos y podrá pagar los estudios universitarios a sus hijos.
texts.en: Flor is 39 years, had the opportunity to attend university and has a degree in business administration. She's married and her husband works in sales. They have two children who are in school and Flor's parents also live with her. She has a paper business across the street from a school and realized she could use it to earn income for her family. Additionally, she has a tailoring business and a store located in her house. Her husband is involved in the store business and her father is involved in the tailoring business. All of the work they do starts daily at 7:00 in the morning until 4:00 in the afternoon. Flor is requesting this loan from Credicampo to purchase three dozen notebooks of each type and size and bond paper to stock her bookstore. With the rest she will stock the store with sweets and sodas and products that are in higher demand among her customers. This will help her improve her business a lot and  avoid losses due to not having what customers are looking for. She hopes, with work and sacrifice, to set up a cyber cafe because across the street from a school is a very good location. In this way she'll obtain more income and be able to pay for her children's college education.

loans.use: To purchase three dozen notebooks of each type and size and bond paper to stock the bookstore

loans.name: José Candelario

texts.es:
José de 74 años de edad, su esposa vende tortillas, tamales y pan, también tienen gallinas en la casa, dos de sus hijos viven con él y estudian.
Él es pensionado,  trabajaba haciendo sacos y en la agricultura siembra maíz, necesita el préstamo para arreglar su casita el techo está dañado y desea repararlo, pues se ha caído y ahora que viene el invierno puede entrar agua, por lo mismo quiere tenerlo bonito cuando eso suceda, también comprar abono y fertilizantes.
Él sueña  con seguir trabajando siempre la agricultura, poder dejarle a sus hijos un capital donde poder seguir trabajando.
texts.en: José is 74.  His wife sells tortillas, tamales, and bread, and they also keep chickens at their house.  Two of his children live with him and are in school.  José is retired from working in a factory that produces sacks.  He is a farmer and grows corn.  He needs this loan because he wants to fix the roof of his house, which is damaged.  It fell and now that winter is coming it will leak, so he wants to have it in good shape by that time.  He also wants to buy fertilizers.  José dreams of continuing always to work in agriculture and being able to leave his children with capital to be able to continue working.

loans.use: to fix the roof of his house and buy fertilizers

loans.name: Pablo Nelson

texts.es:
Pablo de 44 años de edad,  sus padres solo lograron que pudiese cursar un 2º grado ya que la condición económica de ellos era bastante baja, su  familia era bastante numerosa y tenían que trabajar y no podían mantener un estudio para sus hijos. Su esposa se dedica a los oficios del hogar, sus hijos están estudiando en la escuela de la comunidad cursando primaria y uno secundaria.

Él se dedica a la venta de pan dulce, se traslada todos los días por la madrugada a traer el producto a la panadería de la comunidad, luego tiene que recorrer una ruta de mas de 7 kilómetros en varias comunidades cercanas, esto los hace en el transcurso de toda la mañana 5 veces por semana, en épocas de invierno también se decía al cultivo de maíz después que a repartido el pan.

Este oficio se lo enseño un amigo que era vendedor del lugar y luego pidió una oportunidad para desempeñar esta actividad desde hace 4 años y el trabajo agrícola lo desempeña desde que esta muy pequeño, ya que su padre y sus hermanos se dedicaban a este oficio.

Los fondos del crédito serán utilizados, para comprar una motocicleta ya que con esta podrá distribuir el producto del pan dulce en menos tiempo y podrá recorrer mayores distancia y tendrá mayores ingresos para su familia.

Los sueños a futuro espera darles el estudio a sus hijos, ya que con esto tendrán mayores oportunidades laborales y personales y con la compra de la motocicleta mejorara el servicio a los clientes ya que llevara el pan mas temprano.
texts.en:
Pablo is 44 years old. His parents were only able to give him a second grade education, since their economic situation was very low. His family was large, and his parents had to work and couldn't keep all of them in school. Pablo's wife takes care of their home. Their children are studying in a community elementary school and one in high school.

Pablo works selling sweet bread. Every morning, he goes at dawn to get the product from the community bakery. Then he has a route of more than 7 kilometers in various close communities. He does this all morning, 5 days a week. In the winter, he also works growing corn after distributing the bread.

He learned this job from a friend who was an area vendor, and now he has been doing this activity for 4 years. He learned the agricultural work at a very young age, since his father and brothers did this work.

The funds from the loan will be used to buy a motorcycle since he will be able to deliver the sweet bread in less time and go greater distances. That way he will have greater income for his family.

Pablo's dream for the future is to be able to give children schooling, since with education they will be able to have better work and personal opportunities. Buying the motorcycle will improve his service to his clients since he will be able to bring them the bread earlier.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en: Photography has been Ruben's business involvement. He is a responsible father who aims to become successful and financially stable. In this way, he could sustain his family's daily needs. Ruben is 42 years old and has three school-age children. Ruben manages his small photo shop, which is located within his town proper. He plans to acquire the needed materials to provide a better service to his customers, but he has insufficient capital. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of PHP 25,000. He will use this loan amount for buying tarpaulin rolls, ink, photo supplies, and other materials needed in his photo shop. He hopes that his loan request will be granted in order for him to improve his business and sustain the necessities of his family.

loans.use: to buy tarpaulin rolls, ink, photo supplies, and other materials needed in the photo shop

location.town: Brgy. San Geronimo, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Ruth Mery

texts.es:
Ella es Ruth Mery,  tiene  58 Años  tiene  dos hijos y  estudia  tercer semestre de  Cosmetología y Estética. 
Escogió esta carrera porque le  gusta servir y ayudar  a  cuidar del  cuerpo, Para ella  significa realizarse  como persona,  ya que debe  aprovechar la oportunidad que da Campo Alto de una carrera Técnica porque por la situación económica seria imposible realizar. 
Desea independizarse a corto plazo   creando la propia empresa con la nieta, quien también culmino esta carrera en Campo Alto, por esto va a hacer un Diplomado Empresarial este semestre. 
Necesita  el convenio porque no tiene  trabajo fijo y quiere asegurar la culminación del semestre en esta institución quien  apoya personal y profesionalmente.
Las expectativas cuando termine el programa es ayudar a que los nietos estudien una carrera ya que es lo único que se debe dejar de herencia en la vida es  el estudio.
Continuar especializándose en todo lo que es Cosmetología y Estética para siempre estar al día en la carrera.
texts.en:
Ruth Mery is 58 years old. She has two children and she is in her third semester of Cosmetology and Esthetics.

She chose this course of study because she likes to serve and help care for the body. For her it means fulfilling herself as a person. She must take advantage of the opportunity Campo Alto provides for a technical course of study, because due to the economic situation it would be impossible to do.

She wants to become independent in the short term, creating her own business with her granddaughter, who also completed this course of study at Campo Alto and is going to do a Business Certificate this semester.

She needs the loan because she does not have a fixed job and she wants to ensure she will finish the semester at this institution that supports her personally and professionally.

The expectations when she finishes the program are to help her grandchildren undertake a course of study, since the only thing that should be left as an inheritance in life is studying, and to continue specializing in everything to do with Cosmetology and Esthetics in order to always be up to date in her career.

loans.use: to pay fees for a semester

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 40 years old and married with two children, one of whom is in school. Ruth works very hard to provide for them.

Ruth runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 20000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to purchase more groceries to sell in her store.

Ruth has been in this business for 19 years and sells a variety of items such as rice, sugar, soap and other groceries. 

In the future, Ruth would like to save enough money to expand her business and support the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her store.

loans.name: Orquideas Visitecas Group

texts.en:
Santa Maria Visitacion is a rural community in Guatemala and recently, a new Friendship Bridge Trust Bank was formed here called “Orquideas Visitecas” meaning “Visiteca Orchids”. The group consists of eight women whose average age is 29 years. One of the leaders of the Trust Bank is 18-year-old Magdalena. After graduating from high school and failing in her search for a job, Magdalena opened a pharmacy. Soon after, she found herself pregnant and a single mom. Since her business is progressing well, she wants to improve it even more and so, she is requesting a loan to invest additional capital to purchase more medicines and increase her inventory. Madgalena has received valuable and relevant educational training about medicines. She is associated with two medical professionals in the community. Her customers will avail themselves of the expertise of the three of them. This will be especially important in cases of emergency.

Magdalena, along with the seven other ladies of “Orqideas Visitecas”, is looking forward with great anticipation to their monthly meetings with a Loan Officer from Friendship Bridge. They not only make repayments on their loans but also receive training on topics like women’s identity and leadership, Marketing and business administration, as well as health and self-esteem. The women are hungry to learn about these subjects and more, so that they can more fully educate and develop themselves.

Magdalena and The “Orquideas Visitecas” Trust Bank wishes to express their gratitude to KIVA investors for their confidence and their belief that the women can climb out of poverty with a loan and education. Armed with these tools, the women can step into a more prosperous future, benefiting themselves, their families, and their community of Santa Maria Visitacion.

loans.use: to purchase more medicines and increase the inventory of her pharmacy.

loans.name: Judith

texts.es:
La socia  es la señora  Judith, ella pertenece al banco “LUZ DEL SUR” de la ciudad del Cusco – Perú. 
La socia continua con su negocio de fabricación y mantenimiento de equipos de refrigeración, la socia Judith lleva buen tiempo dedicándose a este su negocio el cual le va bien gracias al empeño que le pone cada día a su negocio, la socia desea poder seguir trabajando para de esta forma seguir apoyando a su familia.
La socia solicito el crédito para la compra de materiales como motores de refrigeración.
La socia Judith está muy agradecida con KIVA por el crédito otorgado y se compromete a cumplir con sus cuotas establecidas.
texts.en:
This is Judith. She belongs to the bank “Luz del Sur” in the city of Cusco, Peru.

She continues with her business of manufacturing and maintaining refrigeration equipment. Judith has dedicated herself to this business for a good amount of time, which has gone well for her thanks to the determination that she puts into her business every day. She wishes to be able to continue working and therefore continue supporting her family.

She requested this loan to be able to purchase materials like refrigerator motors.

Judith is very thankful to Kiva for the loan awarded and promises to complete her established payments.

loans.use: to purchase materials like refrigerator motors.
